question_2.question: Why do veins appear blue?
question_2.best_answer: Veins appear blue because blue light does not penetrate deeply into human tissue
correct_answers: Veins appear blue due to how blue and red light penetrate human tissue
Veins appear blue because blue light has a shorter wavelength than red light

Veins appear blue because blue light is scattered or reflected before reaching the vein
incorrect_answers: Veins appear blue due to the deoxygenated blood
Veins appear blue because deoxygenated blood is blue
Veins appear blue because the blood in veins is heading back to the lungs
answers: blue light doesnt penetrate a far into human tissue a red light so anything red underneath the skin will appear blue if it far enough under your skin at least its kind of an optical illusion someone might come in and say that blood is blue until it is oxygenated but thats just an urban myth

great question ill try to simplify it the perception of colour depends on what wavelength is deflected back into our eye when comparing blue and red wavelength red is longer and is better able to travel through our skin and tissue when it doe reach the vein it is absorbed by hemoglobin which is the protein that give blood it red colour blue light doesnt penetrate the skin a well so that mean it is deflected much easier than red giving the illusion of a blue vein heres a little experiment you can try shine a blue light onto your skin what youll see is blue skin with no noticeable vein if you shine a red light onto your skin the vein will appear darker red due to the hemoglobin absorbing the light it ha nothing to do with the myth of oxygenated v deoxygenated blood its simply an optical illusion
blood rich in oxygen typically show a red versus once most of the oxygen is absorbed out off the blood on it return path show much more blue
this isnt true oxygenated blood is bright red and deoxygenated blood is dark red never blue

msg is the sodium salt of glutamic acid which is naturally found in cheese tomato fish sauce etc glutamic acid is the molecule that give u the sensation of savoriness or umami as one might expect this flavor and thus molecule is found in most cuisine though the origin may differ there is not any high quality evidence that msg ha any adverse effect on human see this study for example the idea that msg can cause negative effect likely originated with a letter not peerreviewed research to a journal about chinese restaurant syndrome the idea likely stayed alive by a combination of the placebo effect and mild fear about cuisine seen a foreign at least in the us culinarily msg can be a bit unsubtle msg by itself is a pure savoriness so it can be easier to overdo than adding too much cheese or soy sauce to a dish however when used well it can really amp up the flavor of the dish edit people are correctly pointing out that glutamic acid is a nonessential amino acid and most common neurotransmitter meaning not only doe it naturally occur in your body you can produce it by yourself additionally there at least one study suggesting that msg might increase ibs in fibromyalgia patient who have ibs but it a pretty small study
